Headline: Polymath | ENOVIA Product Marketing | ENOVIA & 3DEXPERIENCE Portfolio Expert
Building a bionic arm for India @Symbionic
Comment:
Taking this train of thought a step further, I feel like the interpretation of the data and research involved wrt improvement in fitness causes a lot of friction for people pursuing any fitness goal. 

Along with the HOW biomarkers are changing and WHY they are, if there was a way to continously suggest areas of improvement and tactics from personalized data collection, it would remove a great deal of friction from the process and possibly increase adherence.  

I believe this is done on a case by case basis by personal trainers and nutritionists now, but could be done on a larger scale with the right methods to collect the personalized data. (Mostly because finding good nutrionists and personal trainers who are trustworthy is hard, which I exactly what believe Fittr is solving)

PS: Will it be possible for you to share the 500+ companies solving for health/fitness in a repository of some sort?, I'm sure it would be helpful for a lot of us.

Headline: Founder-Genefitletics|IEAlumni|Built Asia‚Äôs premier system biology platform to early detect metabolic diseases, autism & oral cancer|Molecular Biochemistry |Transforming human biology into molecular data warehouse
Comment:
Understanding origin & progression of disease ( THE WHY) is the key. However, there is huge gap before wearables could decode. The current wearable tech is nothing but a small pie in disease management opportunity.

 For instance, CGM can tell you spike in blood glucose/blood sugar response/levels. But this does not help until we have info & data on GLUT 4- the protein that goes to cell membrane, bind to glucose, clear it from circulation & transport to cell for storage or energy. Therefore data on molecular signalling that activates GLUT 4 is the key.

Similarly, we may know HRV but unless we decode /measure norepinephrine and epinephrine levels or histamine signalling, HRV is of no use

If I am remember correctly, we had a brief call with your team a month back but I think there was gap in understanding our business model/ or the call was more of idea/innovation shopping.
processed_comment: understanding origin progression of disease the why is the key however there is huge gap before wearables could decode the current wearable tech is nothing but a small pie in disease management opportunity for instance cgm can tell you spike in blood glucoseblood sugar responselevels but this does not help until we have info data on glut the protein that goes to cell membrane bind to glucose clear it from circulation transport to cell for storage or energy therefore data on molecular signalling that activates glut is the key similarly we may know hrv but unless we decode measure norepinephrine and epinephrine levels or histamine signalling hrv is of no use if i am remember correctly we had a brief call with your team a month back but i think there was gap in understanding our business model or the call was more of ideainnovation shopping

Headline: Progress not perfection!
Comment:
In my experience building an Electronic Health Record(EHR) this is extremely difficult to implement.

Here's why: Root cause diagnosis has to be done by General Medicine doctors and not specialists because only root cause can tell exactly "Why" and this is how the process would flow for that:

Chief Complaint/Symptom
Clinical Finding
Differential Diagnosis
Chronic conditions(if any)
Genetic conditions(if any)
Social Behaviours that can cause a condition
Allergies
And Lab Tests to validate

All these factors are necessary to know WHY. Now am assuming that you don't want it to exactly be a 100% but if it's not atleast "quite accurate" then the "Why" can scare the customer especially since most of the these wearables have a lot of inaccuracies. And having all this data captured by a wearable or otherwise is an expensive affair in my experience.

And most importantly the "Why" is difficult even for a doctor to find. That's why it's called a Differential Diagnosis. #myexperience

I think the WHY for a certain bodily reaction is going to be difficult because the body is a complex machine and multiple things can trigger the same reaction. For example: The cortisol can rise due to a life threatening situation or just work stress.

Headline: Storytelling & thought-leadership for Founders + VCs ‚Ä¢ Spicy content marketing for startups ‚Ä¢ Public speaker ‚Ä¢ #womeninbusiness üë©‚Äçüíª
Comment:
Interesting take. I've had a chance to think a bit deeply on this (not as much however as I want to!) - and please take this with a grain of salt. 

I think research backed, innovation-led health startups are the future that solve ONE critical thing. Or co-related things. 

Example, there is a company solving for UTI diagnostics, they're created a completely new method for it. Another company is finding absolutely new ways to diagnose breast cancer early on. 

Finding the WHY requires research. Diabetes is still a myth, and I've always thought that businesses building around it should have a content gameplan that increases awareness around their solution.
